Articles.Content:
A signal! It's not on any of our usual frequencies, in fact the only reason it was detected is because Jeb spilled coffee on the comms panel. Unfortunately, we don't know what it says, as it's in a completely... alien... language.

Our radio guy, Kerboni, has made the approximate range from Kerbin as 0.00km, outbound, which means it was coming from somewhere on the surface and directed into space. Long range satellite triangulation has it coming from somewhere on the Northern ice cap. Your mission, should you decide to accept it, is to go there and investigate whatever you find and bring back ground samples from the vicinity of whatever's up there.

There are, however, a few problems with equipment:

- You don't have access to rockets. All we have in the shop is a rack of air breathing jets and liquid fuel systems.

- Oxidiser is NOT available.

- We have no robot probes to give for this mission, and we only have one cockpit which we were going to use for an aerobrake test prior to the Duna mission but we'll let you have that for this one - it takes precedence right now.

- All our external command chairs are down with a problem with the suit heating systems, so they're not available either.

{SPUDHEAD} The area in question is located near 81 57N, 128 39W, in a mountainous region which makes unsuitable conditions for a longstrip landing. I would suggest some sort of STOL aircraft. {/SPUDHEAD}

**Normal "no 'sploits" rules apply.**

Mission completion:

Specs of your aircraft (photo in hangar with info would be nice)

Photo of aircraft in flight

Photo of aircraft landed at scene

Photo of your crew disembarked at scene

Shot of ground sample science

Photo of your aircraft landed back at KSC or The Island strip, crew disembarked in front of aircraft

Shot of Mission Completion screen (F3)

All screenshots should show the MET (Mission Elapsed Time) clock in the top left corner.

This is intended as a fun mission, the parameters are set, a specific coordinate is given to travel to and return from with science. Free mods but remember you're restricted in terms of the powerplants and control mechanisms available to you. Of course, depending on what you find up there, you might want to leave a guard contingent to make sure nobody else stakes a claim...?

My first run:

The TransKerbal Heavy Airlift: 8 B9 stock variable inline intakes, 8 B9 stock jets.

The wings were 2 clicks up angle and the cruise attitude was +9.1 degrees at 470m/s@15,000m. So a pretty severe angle of attack, and I'd have to say a pretty inefficient design - though for some unknown reason I made the ice cap having burned less than 2500 LF, I had expected to be doing the landing with shy of half left. At that rate I could circumnavigate Kerbin just by setting cruise attitude and going making dinner

With gear down: yes, a tailhook and lots of pods dropping out of the engines and wingtips, this thing wanted to bounce and skid sideways down the runway, it needed all the tyres it could get.

One problem I found with this particularly unimaginative design is that it doesn't handle fairly average airbreather altitude very well. In fact, at 18220m it flamed out one side completely and went into a powered flat spin, this was the inevitable result:

...yes, directly over the landing site! I had planned on just doing an aerial survey as this plane had a ridiculous takeoff roll (it required the entire runway) and a minimum takeoff roll, fully laden, of 135m/s! No way would it have done a short landing on ice and rotate to take off again in the same short stretch.

Edited January 29, 2014 by ihtoit
example (failed) mission

Bullet list of rules and restrictions would be nice, it's not hard to miss an important bit in load of free text not relevant to execution.

How do we win this anyway? Fastest time? Lightest craft? Most Kerbals?

What about mods?

What about mods?

there ya go, not so much fixed as clarified.
